journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering

title-group.article-title: Radar-based target identification and tracking on a curved road

contrib-group.aff: State Key Laboratory of Automotive Safety and Energy, Tsinghua University, Beijing, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: *State Key Laboratory of Automotive Safety and Energy, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, People’s Republic of China. email: likq@tsinghua.edu.cn

abstract.p: Existing target determination methods for radar only work properly on straight roads, so the application of radar in driver assistance systems, such as adaptive cruise control (ACC), is limited to detecting target vehicles directly in front of the host vehicle. Preceding vehicles around a curve cannot be detected by current radar systems. This paper describes a new algorithm for radar-based target vehicle identification and tracking on curved roads for ACC applications. The key problems are the distinction between target curve entry/exit and lane change and the identification of the host-lane preceding vehicle from the adjacent-lane vehicle while driving through a curve. In order to make a more accurate distinction between curve entry/exit and lane change of the target vehicle, the goodness of fit (GOF) corresponding to these two scenarios is found from the correlation coefficient and by introducing additional distinct criteria that have clear physical meanings. Furthermore, the deviation of the measured lateral distance from a theoretical value is used to estimate whether the preceding vehicle is in the host or adjacent lane. Tests show that this method can identify the position of the target vehicle on a curved road with high reliability.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: Target identification and tracking is an important prerequisite for an adaptive cruise control (ACC) system. Generally, ACC judges whether a preceding vehicle is a target or not using radar. However, existing target determination methods for radar only work properly on straight lanes [1, 2], so the application of radar in ACC is limited to detect target vehicles directly in front of the host vehicle. Preceding vehicles around a curve cannot be detected by current radar systems [3]. On a curved road, the vehicle in the adjacent lane can be mistaken as the target, resulting in an incorrect reaction of the ACC [4], potentially causing an accident. To solve this drawback, a fusion system can be implemented. Some fusion systems use vision or other sensors to detect the lane markers and estimate the curvature of the road, then track the target with radar or lidar [5–7]. There are also some fusion systems using both cameras and radar to detect the target vehicles, fusing radar observations and vision contours to estimate the location and motion of the targets [8, 9]. A fusion system can improve the robustness and accuracy of vehicle detection; however, the vision system is still subjected to certain conditions such as bad weather and illumination. Another existing approach is to estimate the curvature with a digital road map [10]. However, the method is not often appropriate for real-time safety applications due to the lack of robustness against map data errors (in China, owing to some restrictions on global positioning systems for civil use, the positioning error of navigation systems is always more than 15 m) and the increase in cost for cars without navigation systems. Some roadside passive reflectors are set to improve radar reliability on curves and at intersections [3]. The reflectors can indirectly increase the beam-width angle of the radar by redirecting the radar beams in a chosen direction; however, it is hard to install the reflectors on every curve of the highway. In addition, the path prediction purely using radar was proposed, but it was insufficient for non-uniform roads and transient manoeuvres [11]. A new method based on the phase chart between the relative velocity and the azimuth angle [12, 13] distinguished the target vehicle lane change and curve entry/exit. Its distinction criterion was decided empirically and did not work properly in some conditions.

A method for radar-based target identification and tracking in curves is proposed in the current paper. In order to make a more accurate distinction between preceding vehicle curve entry/exit and lane change, the goodness of fit (GOF) corresponding to the two conditions is checked through their correlation coefficients and additional distinguishing criteria that have clear physical meanings. If the preceding car has been identified as changing lanes, the radar will release it as a target, and the ACC vehicle will not follow it. If it has done a curve entry/exit, the preceding vehicle will continue to be identified as a target vehicle. Furthermore, the relative lateral distance between the ACC vehicle and the preceding vehicle is estimated based on a single-clothoid road model. The host-lane and the adjacent-lane preceding vehicles in a curve are distinguished by a t-test algorithm. Then, if it is driving in the host lane, the preceding car will be identified as a target vehicle. Tests show that the target vehicle in a curve can be identified and tracked exactly by this method.

sec.title: 2 Difficulty of Radar-Based Target Tracking
sec.p: There are two difficult problems when using radar to realize target tracking on a curved road. First, it is difficult for the radar to distinguish the preceding vehicle’s curve entry/exit from a lane change. This has been discussed in detail in references [12] and [13]. Second, a preceding vehicle in the adjacent lane will cause the radar to make a wrong judgement, as shown in Fig. 1. It will cause the ACC vehicle to follow the wrong target. Here, the host lane means the lane in which the ACC vehicle is driving. The adjacent lane means the lane that is next to the host lane.

caption.p: The disturbance of an adjacent-lane vehicle

sec.title: 3 Distinction between Curve Entry/Exit and Lane Change
3.1 Determination of target vehicle lane changes
sec.p: It has been shown in reference [13] that the relation between the azimuth angle and the lateral component of the relative velocity in a lane change can be expressed by an elliptic equation
where

and θ, Vlat, VH, d, RT, and W are the azimuth angle of the preceding vehicle against the bore-sight of the host, the lateral component of the relative velocity, the velocity of the host, the distance between the host and the preceding vehicle, the radius of the curve on which the preceding vehicle is driving, and the width of the lane, respectively. D is the distance necessary for a lane change. Assuming that the host and the preceding vehicle have the same velocity in the following mode, D = VHtD, where tD is the time needed for a lane change, tD = 4–8 s.
The elliptic equation (1) can be converted into a quadratic equation

The radar outputs with a sequence of (θ[i], Vr[i]). Vr is the relative velocity between the host and preceding cars. Then, Vlat can be found as Vlat = Vrsinθ≈Vrθ. Then, (θ[i], Vlat[i]) is applied to equation (4) using a least squares regression. If the GOF of the regression is high, the manoeuvre can be judged as a lane change. Some criteria were addressed in reference [13] to judge whether the GOF of the regression is high or not; however, these criteria were decided empirically and will not work properly in some conditions. There must be some judgement criteria that have clear physical meanings and are suitable for most driving conditions. Hence, a correlation coefficient method [14] is applied here to test the GOF of the regression, and the lane width relative error is also used as an additional distinguishing criterion.
The factors of equation (4) can be calculated by inserting equations (2) and (3) into equation (1)

It is assumed that the factors of the regression equation are a0*, a1*, and a2* (* indicates that the factors are obtained by regression and are estimated values). Then, the regression equation can be expressed as
The total correlation coefficient (TCC) is calculated using

By applying equations (5–8), the lane width can be estimated using equation (11). The actual lane width is assumed to always be constant. The relative error between the estimated lane width and the actual, shown as equation (12), is introduced as an additional criterion to judge whether the regression has high GOF
where W* is the estimated lane width and Clane is the relative error.
If equations (10) and (13) are both satisfied, the preceding vehicle can be judged as completing a lane change
where clane is the criterion clane = 0.4.

sec.title: 3.2 Determination of target vehicle curve entry/exit
sec.p: According to [13], when the preceding vehicle is entering a curve and the host is still on the straight line, or if the preceding vehicle exits from the curve and the host is still in the curve, the relation between the azimuth angle and the lateral component of the relative velocity can be expressed by a parabolic equation
The factors of equation (14) can be calculated using
where RH is the radius of the curve on which the host vehicle is driving.
Applying the sequence (θ[i], Vlat[i]) to equation (14) using least squares regression, the factors of the regression equation are b0*, b1*, and b2*. Then, the regression equation can be expressed as
The TCC is calculated using

where θi*, θi, and
θ
¯
are the estimated azimuth angle using equation (18), the actual azimuth angle and the average of the actual values.
The probability that the radar output sequence satisfies equation (18) is higher than 95 per cent if equation (20) is satisfied
In addition, the velocity of the host vehicle can be estimated by equations (15) to (17)
The relative error between the estimated host vehicle velocity and the actual value is introduced as an additional criterion to judge whether the regression has high GOF
If equations (20) and (23) are both satisfied, the preceding vehicle can be judged as completing a curve entry/exit
where cv is the criterion cv=0.4.

sec.title: 4 Distinction between Host and Adjacent Lanes
sec.p: Tests show that there are obvious deviations between the lateral distance of the host-lane preceding vehicle and the adjacent-lane preceding vehicle relative to the host vehicle in curves. Hence, the relative lateral distance can be another criterion for distinction. First, the theoretical lateral distance of the host-lane preceding vehicle relative to the host vehicle is calculated. Then, the deviations between the theoretical values and the measured values can distinguish the host-lane vehicle from the adjacent-lane vehicle.

When the preceding vehicle is judged as completing a curve entry/exit, the regression factor b2* equals b2 in ideal conditions. Inserting cT=1/RT and cH=1/RH into equation (17) gives the instantaneous curvature of the preceding vehicle
where cT and cH are the instantaneous curvatures of the preceding and the host vehicles. cH is estimated by the yaw rate of the host vehicle

Equation (25) only reflects the true curvature when the vehicle in steady state is turning. However, in real driving situations, the driver always adjusts the steering angle and speed. So, when applying cH to calculate the theoretical lateral distance, it will result in an instantaneous error. A sequence of data can be evaluated using the t-test method to weaken the influence of errors caused by equation (25), which will be discussed below.
A road segment ahead of the host having curvature c(dx) is modelled by a single-clothoid road model [15, 16], as described by

where c0 is the instantaneous curvature of the host, c1 is the coefficient of linear variation of curvature with distance, and dx is the longitudinal distance from the host, shown in Fig. 2. It is further assumed here that the curvature is not large, that dx≈d and that the relative lateral distance at dx can be calculated from
Comparing equations (24) and (26), c0 and c1 can be calculated using

Inserting equation (28) into equation (27) and assuming that the host-lane preceding vehicle is running along the mid-line of the lane, the theoretical value of the lateral distance between the host-lane preceding vehicle and the host can be calculated using

Because of measurement errors and other disturbances, such as cH estimated by equation (25), the measured value does not always equal the theoretical one. Hence, a t-test method is introduced here to test the degree of divergence between the host-lane vehicle and the adjacent-lane vehicle.
The degree of divergence is expressed by

where dy_act[i] is the measured lateral distance value, dy[i] is the theoretical value calculated using equation (29), dy_err[i] is the error, and

is the average of dy_err[i], i=k – (n+1), k – (n+2), …, k.
If equation (31) is satisfied, the probability that the measured values equal the theoretical ones is higher than 95 per cent [14], i.e. the preceding vehicle is assumed to be in the host lane if

sec.title: 5 Evaluation by Simulation and Field Tests
5.1.1 Curve entry/exit and lane changes
sec.p: This simulation is completed using Matlab. The path comprises a straight, curved, then straight road as shown in Fig. 3. The radius of the curve is 500 m. It is assumed that the host and the preceding vehicles have the same velocity, 108 km/h. The initial longitudinal distance is 60 m. The preceding vehicle leaves the host vehicle’s lane at t = 3 s, returns to it at t=11 s, enters the curve at t=25 s, and exits it at t=51.3 s. The width of the lane W=3.75 m.

caption.p: Path for the curve entry/exit and lane-change simulation

sec.p: The simulation results are shown in Figs 4 and 5. The method works precisely in both conditions. In Fig. 4, γZ is the TCC from equation (9) corresponding to the lane-change regression equation. It can be seen that when the preceding vehicle changes lanes, γZ increases to 1. However, when the preceding vehicle enters or exits the curve, γZ also increases. So γZ itself cannot distinguish between lane change and curve entry/exit. In order to get the correct results, it is necessary to set Clane as an additional criterion. Only when satisfying both conditions, γZ is more than 0.456 and Clane is less than 0.4, can the preceding car be judged as completing a lane change.

Figure 5 shows a similar situation. γθ is the TCC from equation (19) corresponding to the curve entry/exit regression equation. It can be seen that when the preceding vehicle enters or exits a curve, γθ will increase to 1. However, when the preceding vehicle changes lanes, γθ also increases. So it is not enough for γθ alone to distinguish between lane change and curve entry/exit. In order to obtain the correct results, it is necessary to set Cv as an additional criterion. Only when satisfying both conditions, γθ is more than 0.456 and Cv is less than 0.4, can the preceding car be judged as entering or exiting a curve.

The results for the same scenario as in Fig. 3 using the lane and curve methods of [13] are shown in Fig. 6. The lane method is used for detecting the lane change, similar to the method introduced in section 3.1 of this paper. The result shows that when the car changes lanes, the lane method can make a correct decision. However, when the car enters or exits a curve, the lane method also takes it as a lane change. The curve method is used for detecting the curve entry/exit, similar to the method introduced in section 3.2 of this paper. The result shows that when the car enters or exits a curve, the curve method can also make the correct decision. However, when the car changes lanes, the curve method also takes it as a curve entry/exit.

caption.p: Results using the lane method and the curve method

sec.title: 5.1.2 Host-lane and adjacent-lane preceding vehicles in curves
sec.p: This simulation is completed using Matlab. The path comprises curve road, as shown in Fig. 7. The radius of the curve is 800 m. It is assumed that the host and the preceding vehicles have the same velocity, 108 km/h. The initial longitudinal distance is 60 m. The width of the lane is W=3.75 m.

caption.p: Path for host-lane and adjacent-lane simulations

sec.p: In the simulation, the actual lateral distance is calculated using the geometrical relationship shown in Fig. 7. Moreover, taking the radar characteristics into account, a random number, which ranges between −1 and 1 and has a mean of 0, is added to the actual lateral distance. The theoretical value is calculated using equation (29). All of the actual and theoretical values are shown in Fig. 8.

caption.p: Actual lateral distances and theoretical values

sec.p: It can be seen that the actual and theoretical values of the host-lane preceding vehicles are basically the same, but the adjacent-lane values are not.

The t-test method is used to test the degree of divergence of the two groups of data shown in Fig. 8. The results are shown in Fig. 9. This method identifies the target exactly. Namely, it distinguishes the host-lane preceding vehicle and the adjacent-lane preceding vehicle well. The judgement is delayed since the accumulation of data is necessary for regression.

caption.p: Simulation results of host-lane and adjacent-lane distinctions

sec.title: 5.2 Field tests
sec.p: A 77 GHz Denso millimetre wave radar has been installed on the grill of our test vehicle. In order to record the test process, a camera has also been installed in front of the rear view mirror, as shown in Fig. 10.

The vehicle tests were completed on the fourth ring highway in Beijing, as shown in Fig. 11. The longitudinal and lateral distances, relative velocity, and azimuth data were collected, together with the velocity and the yaw rate data of the vehicle. These data were then applied to the developed methods.

The results for lane change detection are shown in Fig. 12. The preceding vehicle left the host lane at t=12.5 s and started to return at t=20 s. The estimator detected the lane departure at t=13.5 s and the return at t=21.5 s. The method worked ideally.
The results for curve entry detection are shown in Fig. 13. The preceding vehicle entered the curve at t=4 s, and the estimator detected the curve entry at t=6.5 s. This also worked effectively.

The results for distinction between host-lane and adjacent-lane preceding vehicles is shown in Fig. 14. At t=4 s, both host-lane and adjacent-lane preceding vehicles entered a curve. The estimation method distinguished the host-lane vehicle from the adjacent-lane vehicle.

sec.title: 6 Discussion
sec.p: A single-clothoid road model is suitable when the curvature is not too small. It is applicable for a highway that often has large radius curves.

Equations (1) and (14) hold true if the velocities of the host and preceding cars are almost the same [12]. This assumption seems to be acceptable for ACC during a stable car-following condition on the highway. However, if the velocities differ too much, this method should be modified. This is one example of our future research.

sec.title: 7 Conclusions
sec.p: A principle of radar-based target identification and tracking methods on curved roads for ACC systems has been proposed. In the simulation and field tests, the validity of the methods is demonstrated. A series of experiments confirm the following:

list-item.p: a correlation coefficient method with additional distinction criteria can modify the identification effect of curve entry/exit and lane changes;
the deviation of the measured lateral distance from the theoretical value can identify whether the preceding vehicle is in the host lane or in the adjacent lane;
the developed methods can achieve target identification and tracking in curves.
